we're also going to see if you can cook salmon ğŸŸÂ

and TikTok on getting stains out of clothesÂ 
and we'll see if any of them work. I've got aÂ Â

that we can put the exact same amount of stainingÂ Â

substance on each one and compare what worksÂ 
best. First up we've got spaghetti sauce of courseÂ Â

and once i've put it on all the shirts i'm thenÂ 
going to get a spoon and scrape it off which iÂ Â

think is what most people do that's what i wouldÂ 
do if i spilled something on my top i wouldn'tÂ Â

just leave a chunk on there. Now for some baconÂ 
grease and some mustard that's always bad andÂ Â

why not a circle of beetroot. Moving on to theÂ 
drinks we of course have to spill some coffeeÂ Â

that seems to be a very common stain, followed byÂ 
some red wine and my favorite hot chocolate. ThisÂ Â

brand new shirt is having a really bad day andÂ 
then we'll add some thick shake over on the side.Â Â

For the adventurers out there here's some mud iÂ 
find that really hard to get out and some grassÂ Â

stains of course, anybody who has little boysÂ 
knows that you need to be able to get them out.Â Â

Now for some grease from the car that's going toÂ 
be tough to get out and some blood. For the schoolÂ Â

kids i'm going to paint some paint on the shirtÂ 
because somehow it seems to manage to get on thereÂ Â

and some permanent marker let's make a nice littleÂ

a scribble of pen ink and some pencil shavings.Â 
Let all of those dry and we now have a niceÂ Â

artistically stained t-shirt the question is willÂ 
any of the hacks get these off or not? let's startÂ Â

with the one from Buzzfeed Nifty this first oneÂ 
says if you spill coffee on your shirt you shouldÂ Â

put vinegar on it then cover it in baking soda getÂ 
more vinegar on a toothbrush and give it a reallyÂ Â

good scrub and then I assume we wash it as normal.Â 
So let's add some vinegar to the stain now vinegarÂ Â

is a weak acid and then we'll add some baking sodaÂ 
which is a weak base and see how that's bubblingÂ Â

that's the reaction between the vinegar and theÂ 
baking soda. When you mix together vinegar andÂ Â

baking soda you get the bubbles of carbon dioxideÂ 
gas which is just a harmless gas that we breatheÂ Â

out and the byproduct the liquid that's leftÂ 
behind is just water and a salt so we've gotÂ Â

carbon dioxide gas and a salty water which i'm notÂ 
sure how that's going to help getting the stainsÂ Â

out but you never know. Let's see. We now have toÂ 
give it a scrub with more vinegar on a toothbrushÂ Â

which makes more impressive looking bubbles moreÂ 
carbon dioxide gas. Now if you happen to spillÂ Â

red wine ğŸ· on your shirt Five Minute Crafts hasÂ

as usual. Now their's looked brand new justÂ 
from pouring the boiling water over it seemedÂ Â

to get it out straight away my stain's beenÂ 
in there for a bit longer than it looks likeÂ Â

there's had so we'll see if that's effective.Â 
Add the salt then pour on the boiling waterÂ Â

that has definitely got some of it out from aroundÂ 
the edges here's the before and after but there isÂ Â

still that stain in the middle we'll have to waitÂ 
and see if that comes out in the wash or not. ForÂ Â

mustard stains Cleaning Solutions channel tellsÂ

the internet's solution to stains. I can do that.Â 
Scrub a dub dub and see how that comes out in theÂ Â

wash. Now what about permanent marker is thereÂ 
a hack for getting permanent marker off clothes?Â Â

Of course there is ... buzzfeed nifty says that ifÂ

a highlighter then add baking soda and lemonÂ 
juice and rub it with a toothbrush of courseÂ Â

and then let it sit for five minutes and wash inÂ

So let's give that a go this one i have put theÂ 
permanent marker on just within the three hoursÂ Â

so we can try it add the highlighter all theÂ

ink to the problem but Buzzfeed's video showedÂ

Well at least it's slightly different to theÂ

scrub it with a toothbrush which seems to beÂ

different bit of fabric with toothpaste smearedÂ

it might actually work so let's test it out. We'veÂ

and scrubbing it with a toothbrush next for blood,Â 
buzzfeed multiplayer says that what we need to doÂ Â

is get water and salt and scrub it with aÂ

the bloodstains and draws it out of the fibres.Â 
Well let's try, salt and water and a toothbrushÂ Â

and scrub. The rest of the hacks for stainÂ 
removing are all very very similar it's basicallyÂ Â

add vinegar then baking soda and if you want someÂ 
dish soap and of course scrub it with a toothbrushÂ Â

that seems to be the internet solution for allÂ 
stains so that's what i'm going to do for allÂ Â

of the rest of them except for the car greaseÂ 
that one i'm going to do something completelyÂ Â

different that i haven't seen online and try justÂ 
putting some oven cleaner on it. I honestly don'tÂ Â

think anything's going to shift the car grease butÂ 
we'll give it a go with that and see if it helps.Â Â

Now earlier last year i was asked to beÂ 
in a TV commercial for a stain removerÂ Â

and that seemed okay to me except for when i toldÂ 
them i don't lie so the product would actuallyÂ Â

have to work. I can't show a new shirt ifÂ 
it didn't come out, when i said that thenÂ Â

they didn't want to work with me anymore soÂ 
that made me very very suspicious ğŸ§ that maybeÂ Â

the stain remover ads are as genuine as some ofÂ 
the youtube hacks that we see. So i thought whyÂ Â

not test the hacks against the stain removers andÂ 
see what performs the best? Let's start with MessyÂ Â

Mouth's stain treatment this one is listed as oneÂ 
of the best sellers on Amazon it says to wet theÂ Â

stain with water then spray on and rub as neededÂ 
now because all of the hacks involved rubbingÂ Â

with a toothbrush i'm going to rub all of themÂ 
with a toothbrush so that that actual motion ofÂ Â

scrubbing it is going to be equal amongst allÂ 
of them. The only thing i want different is justÂ Â

what the stain remover brings to the table. ThenÂ 
it says to launder as usual so for each one i'mÂ Â

going to use one tablespoon of laundry powder andÂ 
the exact same wash settings i'm going to washÂ Â

them all on their own so that any chemicals in oneÂ 
stain remover doesn't mix in the water of the washÂ Â

into the others i want them all on their ownÂ 
so we can actually see if they work. Next weÂ Â

have Shout spray just give it a quick sprayÂ 
there and a scrub with the toothbrush of course.Â Â

Fels-Naptha Soap says to wet the fabric andÂ 
then rub it on the stain and then i'm goingÂ Â

to give it a scrub with the toothbrush toÂ 
make it equal. You might notice that a fewÂ Â

of these turn the red wine from red into a deepÂ 
bluey black colour and that's because red wineÂ Â

acts as an indicator so we can see if it's an acidÂ 
or a base i can show you here if i add a base likeÂ Â

some bicarb it will go darker but if i add moreÂ 
acid like a vinegar it will bubble and react withÂ Â

the bicarb just like we saw earlier but it alsoÂ 
makes the wine change to a redder colour again.Â Â

The stronger the acid or the base the strongerÂ 
the colour change will be. Next we have organicÂ Â

choice pre-wash stain remover enzyme blend thenÂ 
Sard wonderstick. nNxt one is Oxiclean which saysÂ Â

it's America's number one versatile stain removerÂ 
and you can use it in several different waysÂ Â

now one of them involves soaking it for six hoursÂ 
now obviously i can't soak one shirt for sixÂ Â

hours if i'm not soaking the others for six hoursÂ 
because that's a completely uneven experimentÂ Â

the soaking could be what is effective rather thanÂ 
the stain remover itself. So i'm going to use theÂ Â

other method they say for removing stains whichÂ 
is just adding a scoop of it into the wash. OneÂ Â

scoop in every load of laundry it'll make yourÂ 
whites whiter it'll make your brights brighterÂ Â

as a stain remover it's the best, grass stainsÂ 
clay stains long live your laundry! So that one'sÂ Â

easy next we've got the Vanish gold gel this oneÂ 
has a scrubber on the top but i'm not going to useÂ Â

their scrubber i'm going to use the toothbrushÂ 
to keep it even and the same as all the othersÂ Â

and lastly we need a control so for this one i'veÂ 
just got plain water and i'll dab that onto eachÂ Â

one to make it damp and then once that's done i'llÂ 
give it the toothbrush treatment just like allÂ Â

the others and then we can compare how effectiveÂ

This is the control after washing it it hadÂ 
no stain remover as you know just went intoÂ Â

the wash as normal and this is what happened ...Â 
the spaghetti sauce is gone, the beetroot, thickÂ Â

shake, pencil shavings and the paint are all goneÂ 
so those ones didn't even need a stain remover.Â Â

I am surprised about the beetroot but it justÂ 
came out in the wash the most stubborn stainsÂ Â

were the coffee red wine hot chocolate of courseÂ 
the car grease grass stain mud and the ink. TheÂ Â

blood has dissipated but you can still see aÂ 
faint area where it was. So that's the control,Â Â

now what i'm going to do is cut all the shirtsÂ

to the mustard stains for each shirt and eachÂ

with them all spread out across all the differentÂ 
shirts and then we'll know what's most effectiveÂ Â

for what. As you'd expect the ones thatÂ

all the shirts ... here's the beetroot andÂ 
the pencil shavings the bacon grease thatÂ Â

one is really hard to see on camera but itÂ 
does seem pretty good across all the shirts,Â Â

the paint, that was water-based so the controlÂ

you can see on the Sard soap one it's stillÂ 
there faintly spaghetti sauce is gone forÂ Â

all of them except the hack and the Oxiclean whichÂ

because it didn't say to scrub it or rub it i justÂ 
chucked it in i probably should have put water onÂ Â

it and scrubbed it with a toothbrush to make itÂ 
equal to the control but you'll have to keep thatÂ Â

in mind when you're looking at it. The thick shakeÂ 
this one was easy work for all of them didn't needÂ Â

a stain remover for that and now moving on toÂ 
the tougher stains let's start with the mustardÂ Â

you can see the control didn't get out all theÂ 
mustard and neither did any of these ones. TheÂ Â

top row looked better but it's still notÂ 
perfect. If i spilled mustard i would tryÂ Â

any of these four at the top now for the bloodÂ

of these from best to worst going left to rightÂ 
with the top row being the winners for that stain.Â Â

You may notice that different stain removers rankÂ 
better for different stains and that's because theÂ Â

stains that we're trying to get out are made ofÂ 
all different materials so some are going to beÂ Â

more effective on different ones. For grass stainsÂ 
a really important one the control the hack andÂ Â

the Oxy didn't touch it ... these ones all fadedÂ 
but the clear winner was messy mouths. For the mudÂ Â

the Vanish was a little bit better than the restÂ 
definitely a tough stain to get out. For coffeeÂ Â

all of them still have visible staining it'sÂ 
quite hard to choose best because none of them areÂ Â

great. These ones here are the worst and this oneÂ 
is slightly better but it's still not good and youÂ Â

can definitely tell that something's been spilledÂ 
on it. For hot chocolate the bottom row is stillÂ Â

really stained this row is looking a little betterÂ 
but even the best one you can still see a mark.Â Â

What i find interesting in this group is thatÂ 
the control is the second best which means forÂ Â

some reason the stain removers seem to have setÂ 
the stain into the fabric and made it harder toÂ Â

get out, it's made it worse. So with the controlÂ 
being second best that would suggest that water isÂ Â

probably the best solution for hot chocolateÂ 
stains. Moving on to red wine this one was aÂ Â

disaster of a stain here's the control if you justÂ 
chuck it into the wash and to be honest the wholeÂ Â

bottom row looks very similar to the control. TheÂ 
top row seems to have faded it but it is stillÂ Â

there. These two have got rid of that spread butÂ 
the middle is still there and the only one thatÂ Â

seemed to make a significant difference andÂ 
fade it was the Shout. But the stain is stillÂ Â

clearly visible, which makes me ask the questionÂ 
in this advert it says for red wine to just spray,Â Â

rub, wash and it's done it's perfectly white ...Â 
is this the same shirt is it a new shirt or didÂ Â

they just wash it immediately after they spilledÂ 
the red wine on it because we all know that stainsÂ Â

do come out the best if you wash them straightÂ 
away and you don't let them dry out on the shirtÂ Â

but that's not always practical. So i'm not sureÂ 
about that one. Moving on to the crazy stains ifÂ Â

you get car grease on your shirt none of theseÂ

fade it slightly and permanent marker ... wellÂ 
its name says permanent and it's certainlyÂ Â

doing a good job of being just that. This is theÂ

very similar to the control the exception beingÂ 
this one which was the Sard soap it has changedÂ Â

its appearance and this one the hack the redÂ 
hasn't changed or shifted at all but now we haveÂ Â

a yellowy tinge around it from the highlighter soÂ 
definitely do not use that hack on your clothes.Â Â

If you do happen to get permanent marker onÂ 
something special then get some paper towelÂ Â

and put it underneath the fabric then pour onÂ 
some nail polish remover and get another tissue orÂ Â

paper towel on top to quickly soak it out of theÂ 
fabric and draw out some of that permanent markerÂ Â

keep doing that repeatedly until no more isÂ 
coming off the fabric, now you'll see that'sÂ Â

faded it quite a bit but certainly hasn'tÂ 
got it out. So next you want to wash thatÂ Â

and rinse it get all of the nail polish removerÂ 
off it and then put it in some lacquer thinnerÂ Â

leave it to soak for about five minutes and thenÂ 
wash that out and even after all that you canÂ Â

still see the faint outline of what was writtenÂ 
there so permanent marker is pretty permanent.Â Â

Overall the hacks were one of the worst performingÂ 
if not the worst performing stain remover for theÂ Â

spaghetti, the blood, the grass stains, theÂ 
coffee and the mustard so probably not theÂ Â

best to try them the only one worth trying wasÂ 
the one for the pen ink that one actually workedÂ Â

that toothpaste salt and water mixture actuallyÂ 
brought out the pen ink quite well. The ones thatÂ Â

performed best in this test were the Vanish gel,Â 
the fells-naptha, the messy mouths and the shoutÂ Â

and you can rewind back and see which ones workedÂ 
best for which stains depending what you've gotÂ Â

stuck on your clothes. One more hack forÂ 
removing stains that i did not try and i'mÂ Â

not going to try is a five minute craftsÂ 
one they say if you have a grass stainÂ Â

on your clothes then you can squirt eco soap ontoÂ 
it and then just put it in a stream to wash clean.Â Â

Eco soap is not safe for streams lakes rivers theÂ 
ocean it's not designed for that it can reallyÂ Â

upset the ecosystem it can make algae bloom moreÂ 
than it should just keep all soaps whether they'reÂ Â

eco soaps or any type of soap out of thoseÂ 
natural environments it's not good for them.Â Â

Moving on Andy asks is it possible to cook fishÂ 
in a dishwasher i've seen some videos on youtubeÂ Â

sealing food in jars then using the heat ofÂ 
dishwasher to cook it this can't be good right?Â Â

And Jared says this seems ridiculous. So let'sÂ 
have a look in this video blossom's putting salmonÂ Â

into a broth and then into the dishwasher thenÂ 
serving it up instead of using a sous-vide machineÂ Â

wow! There's a lot to unpack there but letÂ 
me test it out so that we can talk about whatÂ Â

happens together. I've got some stock and myÂ 
piece of salmon and i'm putting a temperatureÂ Â

probe into the middle of the piece of salmon soÂ 
we can keep an eye on how the temperature goesÂ Â

obviously this is going to vary a lot dependingÂ 
on how big your jar is, how thick your salmon is,Â Â

but it didn't give us any measurements in theirÂ 
hack so let's just see what happens. I've put thisÂ Â

section of tubing on to protect the thermometerÂ 
cable from the water in the dishwasher and i'llÂ Â

turn the dishwasher on the hottest cycle nowÂ 
on my thermometer probe i'll select fish whichÂ Â

says it will be done at 63 degrees C or 142F thatÂ 
is the temperature we're trying to get it to inÂ Â

order to one cook it but to kill any bacteriaÂ 
that is on the fish if you're talking chickenÂ Â

and other things there's different temperaturesÂ 
but we're just focusing on fish for the momentÂ Â

because that's what we're testing. So you haveÂ 
the cold zone down the bottom and when it's inÂ Â

the cold zone when it's in the fridge and it'sÂ 
nice and chilled the bacteria doesn't multiplyÂ Â

very much but you should always assume that thereÂ 
is some bacteria it's very hard for there to beÂ Â

no bacteria you don't have sterile food. SoÂ 
assume there is some bacteria on it once youÂ Â

bring it up into that warm danger zone that'sÂ 
the temperatures bacteria like to multiply atÂ Â

and they can multiply quite rapidly and the moreÂ 
there is there the more likely it is to make youÂ Â

unwell or get food poisoning from it. So we don'tÂ 
want to keep it in that danger zone but obviouslyÂ Â

we could go through that to get it into the hotÂ 
zone. We want to get it up to 63 degrees and keepÂ Â

it there for at least 15 seconds and then serveÂ 
it immediately you don't want to let it cool backÂ Â

down and you might be thinking about wouldn't youÂ 
have killed the bacteria if you got all the wayÂ Â

up there well yes and no there's different typesÂ 
of bacteria. Some bacteria can form spores whichÂ Â

are heat resistant so it goes all the way up toÂ 
the hot zone you've killed the bacteria but theÂ Â

spores are still there if you bring it back downÂ 
into the warm zone those spores can then germinateÂ Â

and multiply so you want to serve it as soon asÂ 
it gets hot. Now our fish is unfortunately it justÂ Â

falls short now let's imagine for a minute thatÂ 
it had gone hot enough it had gone into theÂ Â

the 63 degrees for 15 seconds well at thatÂ 
point you could probably pull it out andÂ Â

eat it but without the temperature probe you'dÂ 
have no idea where that point is and if you keptÂ Â

opening the dishwasher to measure it, it's notÂ 
going to reach that hotter temperature becauseÂ Â

it's barely getting to that temperature as it isÂ 
and then you can see the temperature dropped offÂ Â

and then it's picking up again that will be theÂ 
final rinse cycle but it certainly doesn't get itÂ Â

hot enough. So we can take that out of theÂ 
dishwasher and the problem here is it's goingÂ Â

to look like it's cooked it's going to tasteÂ 
like it's cooked the cooking isn't the issue,Â Â

the bacteria levels are what the issue isÂ 
so let's not cook food in the dishwasher!Â Â

Now in their video they compared this hackÂ 
to cooking in a sous-vide machine if any ofÂ Â

you have a sous-vide or you've seen one beforeÂ 
and you're familiar with it you might know thatÂ Â

food is cooked at a lower temperature than normalÂ 
they don't necessarily bring it up to that 63Â Â

degrees so how is that okay with food safetyÂ 
and bacteria and everything i've just told you?Â Â

Well there's a couple of differences well threeÂ 
really between dishwashers and sous vide machinesÂ Â

i can't believe i even have to compare theseÂ 
two ğŸ¤ª But number one is in a sous vide you haveÂ Â

to vacuum pack the food so you're eliminatingÂ 
the air and eliminating the oxygen ... a lotÂ Â

of bacteria needs oxygen for it to replicate soÂ 
it needs food it needs the nice warm temperatureÂ Â

and it needs oxygen so getting rid of the oxygenÂ 
means it's not going to multiply and replicate.Â Â

The other difference is a sous-vide machine ofÂ 
course has a controlled thermometer temperatureÂ Â

so you know what temperature the water is inÂ 
the sous-vide machine you're still supposed toÂ Â

use a thermometer probe to know what the internalÂ 
temperature of the food is because the times givenÂ Â

are from when the food comes up to temp not fromÂ 
when the water is at the temperature. The nextÂ Â

and final difference is the length of time thatÂ 
it's held at that temperature so it's kind ofÂ Â

more like pasteurizing the food rather than yourÂ 
normal traditional cooking where we bring it upÂ Â

quickly to that hot temperature hold it there forÂ 
15 seconds and we're done, this is bring it toÂ Â

a temperature that is going to really bother theÂ 
bacteria and hold it there for example if we wereÂ Â

cooking a piece of meat at that sort of lowerÂ 
temperature about 55 degrees centigrade you'dÂ Â

need to hold it there for 90 minutes so an hourÂ 
and a half in a sous-vide machine in order forÂ Â

that to get to the point where it's pasteurized.Â 
It's not a sous-vide machine it's a dishwasherÂ Â

do not cook your food in the dishwasher yes it'sÂ 
hot but no not good for meat or anything likeÂ Â

that it's just not food safe! Moving on someoneÂ

and you put that in the microwave you won't getÂ
